body:
Could you try it with the WKWebView plugin, too? @flavioeverardo  
It could be that this API is only exposed there. (From looking at caniuse WASM support should be in iOS 11+)

@timbru31 I tried this WKWebView plugin:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/cordova-plugin-wkwebview-engine
I installed it with npm and I added the respective code in my config.xml file as stated and still it says that wasm is not supported. 
How can I know that indeed my cordova app is running WKWebView instead of UIWebView?
Should I use the ionic WebView? https://github.com/ionic-team/cordova-plugin-ionic-webview
Also, how can I be sure that cordova is running the proper iOS version?

For your information, I forgot to state that I have the iOS SDK 12.1.
The cordova version is 9.0.0 (cordova-lib@9.0.1)

Thanks again.

> How can I know that indeed my cordova app is running WKWebView instead of UIWebView?

You should see something along this line in the Xcode log when you launch your app from there:

`2019-04-26 14:07:20.150249+0200 HelloCordova[9191:393930] Using WKWebView`

> Should I use the ionic WebView? ionic-team/cordova-plugin-ionic-webview

You can try both, the Ionic WebView is just a fork and renaming of the cordova-plugin-wkwebview-engine

---

My quick test showed that WASM support is not working in a Simulator either (using the regular Safari app) **but is working fine** on my iPhone XS with iOS 12.3 beta with the cordova-plugin-wkwebview-engine!
(I've tested your linked demo and https://webassembly.org/demo/)

Hi @timbru31 thanks again for your help.
Now I'm sure that my app is running WKWebView as shown in the Xcode console.
Initially, I had created the project, add the platforms and then add the plugin (with the additional lines in the config.xml). 
That threw some errors that the Info.plist file was missing and UIWebView was the default view shown in the Xcode console.
To correct this I had to remove the ios platform:
```cordova platform remove ios```
and afterwards add it again with the ```--save``` flag:
```cordova platform add ios --save```

Now the WKWebView is set as the default view. As you said, I had no luck to see the app working with the simulators. 
On the other hand, I'm glad that you tried a couple of options and they work with a device. Unfortunately, I don't have access to devices supporting iOS 12+. 
I will ask someone to test the app or ask someone to lend me a device to test it so we can close the issue.

Regards,
Flavio
Awesome! I might find enough time tomorrow to test an iPad with iOS 11, too.

Any traction on this?  I still have not heard if anyone else is experiencing anything like this, but it happens every time for me.  No location permissions are added for Android, which makes my app in particular a brick ‚òπÔ∏è
Could you provide copy-pasteable shell commands to reproduce this issue? Or a MWE if it's more complex? That could increase the chance of someone confirming this. Sorry for having you wait.

Yeah, sorry I should have narrowed this down sooner.  Basically, I just started with a simple `cordova create`.
Here is the package.json I am using:
```
{
  "main": "index.js",
  "dependencies": {
    "cordova": "^9.0.0",
    "cordova-android": "^8.0.0",
    "cordova-plugin-geolocation": "4.0.1"
  },
  "cordova": {
    "plugins": {
      "cordova-plugin-geolocation": {}
    },
    "platforms": [
      "android"
    ]
  }
}
```

And here is the config.xml:
```
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
<widget id="io.cordova.hellocordova" version="1.0.0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/ns/widgets" xmlns:cdv="http://cordova.apache.org/ns/1.0">
    <name>HelloCordova</name>
    <description>Hello</description>
    <author email="dev@cordova.apache.org" href="http://cordova.io">hello</author>
    <content src="index.html" />
    <access origin="*" />
    <allow-intent href="http://*/*" />
    <allow-intent href="https://*/*" />
    <plugin name="cordova-plugin-geolocation" spec="4.0.1" />
    <platform name="android">
        <allow-intent href="market:*" />
        <!-- <config-file parent="/*" target="AndroidManifest.xml">
            <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.CAMERA" />
        </config-file> -->
    </platform>
    <engine name="android" spec="^7.1.4" />
</widget>
```

If you leave that line commented out and run an `npx cordova prepare`, you will see that the generated `platforms/android/app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml` will have the proper location permissions:
```
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION" />
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION" />
<uses-feature android:name="android.hardware.location.gps" />
```

If you uncomment the lines in the config.xml, however, and re-run your `npx cordova prepare`, it will remove those permissions.

It is worth noting that I do see the following warning on prepare:
```
Conflict found, edit-config changes from config.xml will overwrite plugin.xml changes
```
However, I have always seen that warning, so I thought nothing of it when upgrading to Cordova 9.  Using Cordova 8, I saw that warning, but it still had all of the permissions in the AndroidManifest file.  It may very well be that I should be requesting camera permission in a different way than what I am attempting to do here, because it is clearly not allowing both the way I am specifying and the way the plugin wants to use.  What am I doing wrong?

Thanks,
Eben

Seems to me that sometimes, plugins specify permissions, but sometimes they don't.  I can specify them with a `<config-file>`, but doing so should not overwrite the permissions specified by plugins I have added, right?

> Seems to me that sometimes, plugins specify permissions, but sometimes they don't. I can specify them with a `<config-file>`, but doing so should not overwrite the permissions specified by plugins I have added, right?

Agreed. I'll try to see if I can reproduce your issue. But from first glance, it does _not_ look like it's your fault.
This sounds exactly like https://github.com/apache/cordova-cli/issues/389 and https://github.com/apache/cordova-android/issues/704

@ekrapfl I can reproduce the issue. @dpogue Thanks for linking these issues. Would be great if @knight9999 could look into this. I actually have zero knowledge of the whole `ConfigChanges` code in `cordova-common`.

Hi @timbru31 have you got a chance to test it on iOS 11? 
I can share that fortunately I have the chance to recompile the binary to a asm.js instead of a wasm file. I have tested it with a UIWebView and it works. I imagine that it will work on WKWebView too. 
I also ran it into my old iPad (iOS 9.3) and works too. 
I have not tried it yet on devices with iOS 11 or 12+ but I hope to do it soon.

You can wrap any web app with Cordova. That also includes Angular apps.

Our issues are not for support requests. If you need any further help using Cordova, you should probably ask on [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/) or on our [slack](http://slack.cordova.io/).

Thanks for the workaround, @cyparu!  I was going to give it a shot, but I might need the functions you are importing from `./utils`.  Unless I am missing something there :)

Thanks again!

> 
> 
> Thanks for the workaround, @cyparu! I was going to give it a shot, but I might need the functions you are importing from `./utils`. Unless I am missing something there :)
> 
> Thanks again!

The `utils` module includes some project dependent functions but you can safely remove/neglect them (colors + log exported functions) or just replace the full imports with:
```javascript
var fs = require("fs"),
	colors = require("chalk"),
	log = console.log;
``` 

With this small code change, hopefully the provided work-around will üöÄ for you as well üëç
That does not appear to be working for me, but I am really holding out hope for the true solution here, anyway.  I'm glad you have found a workaround that works for you, though!

I've tested:
* iOS Safari 10.3 - as expected: no WASM support üî¥ 
* iOS 11.4.1 - Cordova app with WKWebView ‚úÖ 
* iOS 11.4.1 - Safari ‚úÖ 

Can we close this issue?

> 
> 
> That does not appear to be working for me, but I am really holding out hope for the true solution here, anyway. I'm glad you have found a workaround that works for you, though!

Did you've properly registered the hook under config.xml ? Check this link ( https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/9.x/guide/appdev/hooks/#configxml )  for additional info on how to use the Cordova hooks.

If you are running `cordova prepare|build android --verbose` ( see: https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/9.x/reference/cordova-cli/index.html#project-command-list ) you should see more info related to hook executions and if everything works fine you should also find the 2 generated files **(AndroidManifest.xml.good + AndroidManifest.xml.bad)** are saved directly under **platforms/android/app** folder

Yes, I added the hook, and it was running.  It was erroring out if I do not have an existing AndroidManifest.xml (ie: first time prepare).  It did not error out when I ran a `cordova platform add android` instead of the prepare (just trying to hit it from a different angle), but in that case, it gave me an AndroidManifest.xml that had even more stripped out of it.  I saw that it generated the `.good` and `.bad`, but neither of them was the one that I would have expected.  The `.bad` was the one that I have previously been getting from `cordova prepare` (makes sense), but the `.good` was an even more stripped down version.  It had less than what the previous one did.
Have an other solutions to replace the node-fs-extra?
@f5cs We've been using a `postinstall` hook to monkey-patch the `fs-extra` dependency after installation on Windows.

Yes sure... I guess we have enough material to close this issue.
Thanks @timbru31

fs-extra are about to release version 8 which apparently has a workaround for this issue.

Will you guys use that once it's out?
How is this coming along? Any decisions been taken? Fs extra is about to release v8 with apparently a workaround for this issue.

@dimitriscsd With "we", I didn't mean Cordova, I meant our company :D But I'm sure Cordova will be updated to use the latest version of fs-extra. Feel free to open a PR when the update is available to help speed up the process.

> fs-extra are about to release version 8 which apparently has a workaround for this issue.
> 
> Will you guys use that once it's out?

If/when there is a version released with a fix, we'll see if we can pull it in without it being a breaking change (which pretty much just means, it needs to support node 6).
Currently working on cordova-plugin-splashscreen

> fs-extra are about to release version 8 which apparently has a workaround for this issue.

jprichardson/node-fs-extra#667

> [...]
> it needs to support node 6

jprichardson/node-fs-extra#667 seems to keep Node.js 6 support in package.json: [[1]](https://github.com/jprichardson/node-fs-extra/blob/bb30e7f1758c0388a8e4cddb48752e83bcb85e8b/package.json#L5-L7)

and tested green so far on AppVeyor: [[2]](https://github.com/jprichardson/node-fs-extra/blob/bb30e7f1758c0388a8e4cddb48752e83bcb85e8b/appveyor.yml#L5)

I would *personally* favor incorporating this update in a minor release due to what I think are some non-trivial changes in jprichardson/node-fs-extra#667

[1] https://github.com/jprichardson/node-fs-extra/blob/bb30e7f1758c0388a8e4cddb48752e83bcb85e8b/package.json#L5-L7

[2] https://github.com/jprichardson/node-fs-extra/blob/bb30e7f1758c0388a8e4cddb48752e83bcb85e8b/appveyor.yml#L5

Please take a look at the recent comments in apache/cordova-common#64, where you should see the answer so far.

If we *do* incorporate a new fs-extra release, I suspect we would do a pipelined release of a number of components including `cordova-common`, some if not all Cordova platform components, `cordova-lib`, and `cordova-cli`.

> * In [apache/cordova-plugin-statusbar#132](https://github.com/apache/cordova-plugin-statusbar/pull/132) the question came up of including the plugin version number in the typings themselves.
> [...]

I would personally downvote that idea. I think that dependent code should be able to code to the interface without regard to what version of the plugin it is using.

> * Are there tools to create these typings automatically?

If the source code is JSDoc annotated, I have seen some tools that will generate the `.d.ts`:

- https://github.com/englercj/tsd-jsdoc
- https://github.com/otris/jsdoc-tsd
- https://github.com/fivetran/typescript-closure-tools (Closure being a style of JSDoc)

I would generally favor using JSDoc with types for the multiple benefits of maintainability, clarity, and [Type Safe JavaScript with JSDoc](https://medium.com/@trukrs/type-safe-javascript-with-jsdoc-7a2a63209b76) (article by @rbiggs).

> I think that dependent code should be able to code to the interface without regard to what version of the plugin it is using.

My formulation might not have been clear enough: The version number is only included in a comment at the beginning of the file, to indicate which version the definitions apply to. There is nothing blocking the use of the definitions with mismatched version number or anything.

Disadvantage is that this creates a new mandatory release step because that number of course has to be incremented with each release.

Well, I agree that such a comment should not exist since naturally the typings in the plugin package apply to the version of the plugin that is in the package which is the version of the package. Easy :)
iOS 10 is finally gone as well and throwing errors.
Success, splashscreen is now vote in progress: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/9cfa884ee3242af9e09c2695346db2375864b4f1a91b45891d7b4de1@%3Cdev.cordova.apache.org%3E

@dpogue Why is node 6 required? Why not just update and use the latest. e.g. 10.x (LTS). I just wondering.
But if I understand it correctly, there is a fallback. It uses node 10 features like biginteger, but falls back to number if not node 10.x. (correct me if I'm wrong.)

> Why is node 6 required?

According to semver rules, we cannot drop Node.js 6 support without making another major release.

For context:

> Why not just update and use the latest. e.g. 10.x (LTS)

Currently ~45% of Cordova users are using node <10.

I think that all Cordova maintainers (including myself) are already overloaded without having to maintain an Application Preferences plugin. I would favor that someone or some people who are so motivated pick up the work and continue with a new plugin name. Please feel free to announce it here or on one of our mailing lists.

Thanks @globules-io. Given the sheer volume of existing web JavaScript libraries and frameworks, I would favor a quick list of unique benefits, how it compares to some close alternatives, and how it compares to some well-known frameworks such as Angular/Vue/React.
Also a functional sample demo or starter project would help anyone else who needs to do something similar.

travis.yml changes have been created as PRs for all plugins. This included going to node 6 for all of these configurations. I wrote a dev mailing list message which gives an overview: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/959ebe1683ac8ac10013d70a514bdf213ac6935ffd28fd045b269ab6@%3Cdev.cordova.apache.org%3E

Now we probably only need PRs for appveyor.yml and possibly updated to package.json.
Nothing we can do about it - either we have to specify the Android version, or the CLI version in the config.
Work ongoing via paramedic changes and rollout to plugin repos.

This exists:

https://github.com/alsorokin/cordova-periodic-build-android
https://github.com/alsorokin/cordova-periodic-build-ios

(Take a look at the Travis build history)

Broken right now, but could be a blueprint on how to create a repo that can test platforms with all plugins.
Work in progress via rollout of https://github.com/apache/cordova-paramedic/blob/master/.travis.yml to plugin repos.
I think having cordova-cli as a devDependency would be an easy and clean solution. Or is it only used in CI, not in local tests?

https://github.com/apache/cordova-paramedic/blob/master/.travis.yml is now the central "template", but rollout still has to happen manually as some plugins do not support some platforms, some have an additional test directory where `npm test` should be run etc etc.
Platforms removed via rollout of https://github.com/apache/cordova-paramedic/blob/master/.travis.yml that is in progress.

Yeah, this is about the Android SDK/tools version being installed by CI that has to be compatible with the pinned cordova-android version of Cordova CLI. New CLI release is automatically installed by CI, but CI config still uses older Android SDK.
Yes, but by specifying a semver range for the CLI in devDependencies that forbids major updates, that could be solved cleanly

Sorry, I might be missing something here:
Won't this limit what version of the CLI can be used with the plugin? 
The problem is not the plugin itself, which is perfectly fine with all Android SDK tooling (it is not relevant), but that the plugin CI has configured a specific Android SDK that can break when a new Cordova CLI is released.

@brodybits have you had time to check out the 47 pages of the wiki? I will try to compile a bullet point list. This was made especially for Webview with Cordova in mind, unlike Angular/React. Didn't think there was enough framework for Cordova... What a weird comment with all due respect.

> Won't this limit what version of the CLI can be used with the plugin?

Not, if you specify a version range as a devDependency or in the CI config as you previously suggested. After taking a quick look at the repo you linked, I'd say that installing a specific version in the CI config makes more sense in this case.

- OGX.JS does not rely on any tech stack, it is highly portable and does not require any compiler
- OGX.JS has templating operations unlike other frameworks, with temporary properties and global var support and loop operations
- OGX.JS supports template-binding to object properties (render different objects within the same list)
- OGX.JS has all the components already built-in so you don't need to code as much as other frameworks to output a pro grade app
- OGX.JS data handling is NoSQL, inspired by MongoDB (via OGX.List or MongOGX) unlike SQL based solutions, including querying, sorting, filtering, and multi level grouping, writing, reading.
- OGX.JS allows binding between components to filter/sort/display
- OGX.JS can transform and render complex datasets via different components with one line, including data trees (transform simple array into data trees and render it with one line via different components)
- OGX.JS is scope based and can render different data depending on the user scope
- OGX.JS is mobile first and has a multitude of components supporting drag, swipe, swipe reveal, reorder, tap-hold-drag-drop
- OGX.JS supports simple popups, tabbed popups, windows, views and tabbed views
- OGX.JS supports multiple virtual apps within an app via a Threater or "stage explorer"
- OGX.JS supports auto blur/focus on all components in/out of the screen
- OGX.JS handles loading, storing and routing via a single app.json config, including preloading fonts, sounds, images, html templates..
- OGX.JS is fully event based
- OGX.JS supports fields and form binding including restrictions, validation and population
- OGX.JS has built in geo operations to work with maps and geo data such as addresses
- OGX.JS has built in color tools
- OGX.JS is thoroughly tested on iOS, Android, including ChromeOS and works also perfectly for PWA's
- And all of the other good stuff a framework is expected to have (history management, locking, dynamic views, display objects and much more).
- You do not need any other tool/library to built complex apps unlike other frameworks that are "programming frameworks". This is a product framework and is the only one of its kind.
I still don't understand. Won't we have to make us update the config/package.json with each (major) CLI release vs. just sometimes when the pinned cordova-android requires a new Android SDK?

> Won't we have to make us update the config/package.json with each (major) CLI release vs. just sometimes when the pinned cordova-android requires a new Android SDK?

That is completely true. Sorry, I might have misunderstood you earlier.

Yes, we will have to decide whether we want to have scheduled maintenance at possibly shorter intervals or regular breakage at possibly longer intervals. I'd rather opt for the first alternative, but I see the appeal in the latter, given the amount of plugins.

IMHO the underlying problem here is that we have too much overhead for simple house keeping tasks. In this case, a mono repo for plugins would probably make things easier.

Ok, at least my understanding of the situation was correct.

Monorepo sounds nice in theory, in practice the even worse chaos in issues and PRs would offset these benefits by a lot.

I think for now we'll keep it like it is. Future updated to the Travis config can easily be scripted as I unified them over all plugins, so this shouldn't be too much work next time.
fs-extra v8 has been released. Just a heads up.

@janpio 

> Currently ~45% of Cordova users are using node <10.

But this is like the Internet Explorer phenomenon. It's more a question of laziness and ignorance. I see it more as a task to bring the people in it. Using the latest versions. Especially for developers, it is important to always be up to date and not to stick to proven versions. For a long time that is not good. 

However, I think it's because these people have not yet updated. But there would be nothing wrong with that. Or are there known issues with Node 10+?

@Domvel Not updating NodeJS isn't always linked to being lazy. Think about companies where you have hundreds of developers. Maybe dependencies you use no longer work in newer versions of Node. There are very good reasons not to update NodeJS constantly.

@oliversalzburg This was not exactly what I meant. It's fine. Do not blindly update the productive environments. The question is, when do these people finally update? I mean only the people and companies that still use Internet Explorer. It's just wrong in every way. No discussion please. üòÑ 
In my case, I persuaded people to stop supporting IE. This should be the mission of every web developer. ... But I digress ... I just refer this. ...

Okay, so using your new script, if I start completely fresh (nuke node_modules, platforms, and plugins), do an `npm install`, and then run `cordova prepare`, then `cordova build android`, I end up with no difference from what I had before adding the hook.  Still missing some of the permissions.

Again, I don't necessarily need the workaround for now, I am just hoping for a fix.  Any news on that front @knight9999 or @raphinesse?
Are you maybe looking for https://github.com/apache/cordova-browser?

**Blog Announcement Reference:** https://github.com/apache/cordova-docs/pull/965
--> Updated Image Timeline: https://github.com/apache/cordova-docs/pull/967

Theoretically there are GitHub apps that can automate the process of generating and adding a TOC to a .md file (e.g. https://github.com/apps/toc-me). 

Practically I suspect that Apache INFRA will not let these apps do changes on our repositories, so we will probably have to do the changes manually (as I did for the splashscreen plugin) and keep them updated manually as well.
For the splashscreen plugin I used http://ecotrust-canada.github.io/markdown-toc/ and adapted the output a bit (mostly fixing the special character stuff anchors it messes up).

What does "quits unexpectedly" mean?
How did you build and install the app?
Did you look at any crash logs or other log files?

@janpio I open the app, and then it just randomly closes. It was fine yesterday, and I haven't done anything, it's been fine every day, but the pattern is this:

It seems to be after about a week, regardless of the app, it randomly quits on opening

How are you building your app? 
What kind of Apple developer account are you using to sign the app?

What you describe could be caused by using a free development account: https://stackoverflow.com/a/46284483/252627
That sounds about right actually, I'm using a "Personal Team" Apple account (not paying), and this sounds about right.

Yes, that explains what you are seeing. Apple got quite restrictive to force people to use a paid Apple developer account (if personal or for a company doesn't matter, as long as you paid them some money so they have a valid billing address for you).
Issue in the correct repo: https://github.com/apache/cordova-plugin-wkwebview-engine/issues/98
Android 4.4 seems to be gone now as well - and I forgot that in the updated `.travis.yml` :/
It might also be worth to get rid of older nightlies in some automated way.

It is possible.

See the `cordova-electron` repo for example: https://github.com/apache/cordova-electron/blob/master/.npmignore

Things I believe should also be excluded from the package:
- Docs
- Test specs
- Raw src files that are not used directly but a part of some build process.
- Third-party configuration files (linting tools, testing frameworks, code formatters, etc.)

Great.

One thing to note: The "vote" procedure usually contains steps to make sure a package actually works, which until now meant running the tests (for plugins for example via the included tests-plugin, and generally via `npm test`). This might conflict with the removal from the package.

Yeah, that might have to change.

I feel they should be excluded because it also has no value to an end user who is only trying to develop their own app. If they want to test our code, at that point they should be using GitHub as a developer for the Cordova product.

IMO, if I am releasing something, I had already ran the tests before I made the package as well as validating the CI services were green which ran the same tests. I feel that the releasers own +1 vote should also mean that they tested since these steps are written in the release guide.

Anyways, this might need to be a later discussion in another ticket or email thread.

Discussion points b) and c): 
Just put it in https://github.com/apache/cordova-contribute, add some documentation and reuse the distribution script used for the GitHub templates: https://github.com/apache/cordova-contribute/blob/master/github-templates.md#distribute-github-templates-to-all-repositories

There is a PR that improves/changes the wording: https://github.com/apache/cordova-contribute/pull/25 It also changes how the checklist works and removed that platform things, which only works on platform specific repositories. See over there for comments and discussion.
What is the CSP of your app/site?

@raphinesse is there any update to share on this?  I know some other issues were mentioned as potentially related.  Unfortunately, this is still completely blocking us from using Cordova 9 and its amazingly fast prepare speeds :(

Unfortunately there is no progress on this that I know of. I understand that this is a serious problem. Incidentally, a personal friend just told me that he's affected by it too. As I stated above, unfortunately I myself am not acquainted with the code responsible for the config changes. Neither do I have time to dive into it right now.

It has been suggested that the bug might be caused by https://github.com/apache/cordova-common/pull/24. So if you should want to take action yourself, you could go ahead and try if reverting that change fixes the bug for you.
Yes so far: https://twitter.com/jcesarmobile/status/1135975882332487681
This definitely is a candidate for a plugin (as it is only needed by some users, also a new API that will probably need some iteration) - but a very interesting one.
wrong repo
I am now closing this issue as a duplicate of #121 which was just transferred from cordova-common.

I just transferred this issue from cordova-common to cordova and closed #83 as a duplicate. Also discussed in the following places:

- <https://github.com/apache/cordova-lib/pull/613#issuecomment-474377440>
- apache/cordova-android#692 / apache/cordova-android#693
- proposed bugfix on cordova-common in apache/cordova-common#70

I hope to get the bugfix on cordova-common released next week, then I think we should update some other packages including cordova-lib, cordova-android, cordova-windows, and cordova-cli.

Please feel free to contact us via email to <dev@cordova.apache.org> in case of any further delays.
Maybe it also makes sense to add the plugin itself automatically!? Then it could all be installed via 1 `plugin add` for the tests.

Is this reproducible in a new, plain Cordova app? A minimal reproduction repository would really help to debug and later fix this issue. More information on how to create one: https://github.com/apache/cordova-contribute/blob/master/create-reproduction.md

cordova-common@3.2.0 is now released with apache/cordova-common#70 merged (Thx! @brodybits)
Will it be available in Npm soon? With updates of the other packages you mentioned too?

> (Thx! @brodybits)

You are welcome.

> Will it be available in Npm soon?

I am still waiting for one more vote from a committer, will publish on npm on Friday if we get the vote in time.

> With updates of the other packages you mentioned too?

I only mentioned some other issues and a PR where a similar problem was reported.

I think the update in `cordova-common` should resolve the issue for cordova-android and cordova-windows platforms since they do not use any other Cordova dependencies.

I would also like to apply the same update to some other Cordova packages, cannot promise when I will have time to do this. Here are the packages I think should be updated when someone gets a chance:

- `cordova-electron`
- `cordova-create`
- `cordova-fetch`
- `cordova-lib`
- `cordova-windows` - update should be done in `devDependencies`, which should only affect end-to-end test script and **not** any end users

Another thing is that I think we should get rid of `superspawn` as discussed in #16, rather than fixing `superspawn` to drop use of `q`. The rationale is that `superspawn` seems to return a non-standard Promise-like object that can also notify the listener of `stdout` and `stderr` data. I think it would be better to cleanly factor `superspawn` out of the Cordova packages, in a major release.

While it would be ideal to do this in the next major release, it would likely block some other desired changes such as dropping support for Node.js 6 and eventually Node.js 8.

@erisu I only wanted to give examples of some major changes that I *know* are wanted in an upcoming releases, and that I think should not be blocked by removing `superspawn` (#16). I suspect that #16 could be a major effort to implement and test on all of the various Cordova packages.

I hope this is clear now. Please feel free to ask if it is still not clear.

Another rationale I gave in <https://github.com/apache/cordova/issues/7#issuecomment-501917531> is that `superspawn` seems to return a non-standard Promise-like object that can also notify the listener of `stdout` and `stderr` data. I think getting rid of `superspawn` would really help finish getting rid of `q` (#7).
